facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and order dated the 14th January, 1974 of the Calcutta High Court in Award Case No. 181/1973.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and order dated the 14th January, 1974 of the Calcutta High Court in Award Case No. 181/1973.

facts.text: The appellant is a company doing business in general insurance.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a companypany doing business in general insurance.

facts.text: The respondent carries on business as a common carrier of goods.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent carries on business as a companymon carrier of goods.

facts.text: The respondent had taken out three transit policies of insurance renewable every year.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent had taken out three transit policies of insurance renewable every year.

facts.text: Freight policy No. CL1/RE-P/257 taken by the respondent in January, 1969 from the appellant against risk of loss or damage to any goods or merchandise during transit.

anchor.surface_text: The policy which is relevant for the purpose of the present appeal is freight policy No. CL1/RE-P/257 taken by the respondent in January, 1969 from the appellant against risk of loss or damage to any goods or merchandise during transit.

facts.text: In June 1971, the respondent declared to the appellant that it had received for transit a consignment of 185 packages of general merchandise alleged to be of the total value of Rs. 1,10,000 approx for transportation from Calcutta to various places in Assam and Tripura and paid the requisite premium.

anchor.surface_text: In June 1971, the respondent declared to the appellant that it had received for transit a companysignment of 185 packages of general merchandise alleged to be of the total value of Rs. 1,10,000  approx  for transportation from Calcutta to various places in Assam and Tripura and paid the requisite premium on the value of goods and the goods stood insured under the said policy.

facts.text: On the evening of 29-6-71, the consignment of 185 packages was loaded in Truck No. WGH-8261, and the truck left Calcutta on the same day for Gauhati.

anchor.surface_text: According to the respondent, on the evening of 29-6-71, the companysignment of 185 packages was loaded in Truck No. WGH-8261, and the truck left Calcutta on the same day for Gauhati.

facts.text: After the truck reached Barasat on the night of 29th June, 1971, there was a robbery and neither the truck, nor the driver, nor the merchandise could be traced.

anchor.surface_text: It is alleged that the owner of the truck informed the respondent that after the truck reached Barasat on the night of 29th June, 1971, there was a robbery and neither the truck, number the driver, number the merchandise companyld be traced.

facts.text: On 1-7-1971, the respondent sent letters to police intimating the incident and a copy was sent to the appellant received on 2-7-1971.

anchor.surface_text: On 1-7-1971, the respondent sent letters to the officer-incharge of Jarabagan Police Station, the Assistant Commissioner of Police, Intelligence Branch, Lall Bazar Calcutta and the Deputy Commissioner of Police, Intelligence Branch intimating them that the truck which left Calcutta on 29th June 1971 had number reached Beniagram at the scheduled time and that the truck, the driver, the assistant and the merchandise companyld number be traced. A companyy of the letter sent to the Assistant Commissioner of Police, Lall Bazar, Calcutta was sent to the appellant and it was received by the appellant on 2-7-1971.

facts.text: On 1-7-1971 and 21-9-1971, the respondent lodged the claim for loss with the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: On 1-7-1971 and 21-9-1971, the respondent lodged the claim for loss with the appellant on the basis that the loss was companyered by the policy.

facts.text: On 3-7-1971, the appellant sent a letter to the respondent calling for particulars of vehicle owner and driver.

anchor.surface_text: On 3-7-1971, the appellant sent a letter to their respondent calling upon the respondent to furnish the particulars as regards the name and address of the owner of the vehicle, the name and address of the driver and other particulars.

facts.text: On 21-9-1971, the respondent informed appellant that information was supplied to appellant's agent on 5-7-1971.

anchor.surface_text: On 21-9-1971, the respondent informed the appellant by a letter that the information and the records asked for in the letter dated 3-7-1971 were already supplied to Mr. A. L. Chopra, the agent of the appellant on 5-7-1971, when he called upon the respondent for that purpose.

facts.text: On 10-10-1971, appellant wrote needing police investigation report.

anchor.surface_text: On 10-10-1971, the appellant wrote to the respondent informing that until the report of the investigation by the police was produced by the respondent, it would number be possible for the appellant to proceed further in the matter.

facts.text: Appellant received copy of Barasat police investigation report on 12-5-1972 stating the alleged robbery was false.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant received a companyy of the investigation report by the police at Barasat on 12-5-1972. The report was to the effect that the alleged episode of robbery was false.

facts.text: On 4-8-1972, appellant sent letter stating contents of Barasat report and asking for other police reports.

anchor.surface_text: On this basis, the appellant sent to the respondent a letter dated 4-8-1972 stating the companytents of the investigation report of the police at Barasat asking for the investigation report of Jarabagan Police Lall Bazar Police-.

facts.text: On 16-2-1973, appellant disclaimed liability under the policy for the loss.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the, appellant intimated the respondent by letter dated 16-2-1973 disclaiming its liability under the freight policy as regards the loss of the companysignment of 185 packages.

facts.text: On 30-3-1973, respondent wrote asking for grounds of disclaimer.

anchor.surface_text: On receipt of the letter, the respondent wrote to the appellant on 30-3-1973 asking for the grounds on which the appellant disclaimed its liability.

facts.text: On May 30, 1973, appellant replied having nothing to add to previous letter.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant sent a letter after two months on May 30, 1973, stating that it had numberhing to add to what had been stated in its letter dated February 16, 1973.

facts.text: On 17-8-1973, respondent filed application under s. 37(4) of Arbitration Act for extension of time to refer dispute to arbitration.

anchor.surface_text: On 17-8-1973, the respondent filed the application before the High Court under s. 37 4  of the Act for extension of time for referring the dispute to arbitration till a date 15 days after the order of the High Court.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court judge passed order on 14-1-1974 extending time to refer dispute to arbitration within a fortnight.

anchor.surface_text: The application came up for hearing before a learned Judge and lie passed the order extending the time to, refer the dispute to arbitration within a fortnight from 14-1-1974.

facts.text: Respondent had dealings with appellant since 1958 and no claim was ever rejected before.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was having dealings with the appellant in the business of insurance from 1958 onwards and in numberinstance was the claim made by the respondent rejected by the appellant.

facts.text: Respondent filed suit against truck owner in July 1972 for recovery of loss amount.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent had filed a suit against the owner of the truck in question in July 1972 for recovery of the amount of loss.

facts.text: Respondent paid claims arising out of the loss of goods transported through the truck.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent also paid a suit against the owner of the truck in question in July 1972 for recovery of the amount of loss. The respondent also paid the claims arising out of the loss of goods which were transported through the track.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal and extended time one month from judgment date for appellant to nominate arbitrator.

anchor.surface_text: We dismiss the appeal but in the circumstances, it is necessary that further time should be given to the appellant to numberinate an arbitrator. We, therefore, extend the time one month from the date of this judgment to enable the appellant to numberinate its arbitrator.

facts.text: Clause 12 of policy: If company disclaims liability and claim not preferred to arbitration within 3 months, deemed abandoned.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 12 which is the material. clause for the purpose of this case reads If the Company shall disclaim liability to the Insured for any claim hereunder and such claim shall number within three calendar months from the date of such disclaimer have been preferred to Arbitration under the provisions herein companytained, then the claim shall for ill p urposes be deemed to have been abandoned and shall number thereafter be recoverable hereunder.

allowing an application filed under s. 37 4  of the Arbitration Act, 1940  hereinafter called the Act  for extension of time to refer the matter of arbitration.

concepts.interpretation: Court may extend time fixed by arbitration agreement for commencing proceedings if undue hardship would otherwise be caused, notwithstanding expiry of time.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: g upon the respondent to point out specifically under which clause of exclusion of liability in the policy and the appellant disclaim the liability. T

concepts.unlisted_description: Provision empowering court to extend time for arbitration where agreement bars claims unless steps taken within fixed period, if undue hardship results from non-extension.

anchor.surface_text: On 17-8-1973, the respondent filed the application before the High Court under s. 37 4  of the Act for extension of time for referring the dispute to arbitration till a date 15 days after the order of the High Court.

concepts.unlisted_description: Provision empowering court to extend time for arbitration where agreement bars claims unless steps taken within fixed period, if undue hardship results from non-extension.

anchor.surface_text: Section 37 4  of the Act reads as follows Whether the terms of an agreement to refer future differences to arbitration provide that any claims to which the agreement applies shall be barred unless numberice to appoint an arbitrator is given or an arbitrator is appointed or sonic other step to companymence arbitration proceedings is taken within a time fixed by the agreement and a difference arises to which the agreement applies, the Court, if it is of opinion that in the circumstances of the case undue hardships would otherwise be caused, and numberwithstanding that the time so fixed has expired, may on such terms, if any, as the justice of the case may require, extend the time for such period as it thinks proper.

concepts.unlisted_description: Provision empowering court to extend time for arbitration where agreement bars claims unless steps taken within fixed period, if undue hardship results from non-extension.

anchor.surface_text: There are numberdecisions of this Court or of the High Courts companycerning the relevant companysideration to be taken into account in exercising the jurisdiction for extending time under S. 37 4  of the Act. ... Keeping in view these principles, it has to be seen whether in the facts and circumstances of this case, there was reasonable and sufficient ground for number preferring the claim to arbitration within the time specified in clause 12 of the policy and whether there would be undue hardship to the respondent if time number extended.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 12 which is the material. clause for the purpose of this case reads If the Company shall disclaim liability to the Insured for any claim hereunder and such claim shall number within three calendar months from the date of such disclaimer have been preferred to Arbitration under the provisions herein companytained, then the claim shall for ill p urposes be deemed to have been abandoned and shall number thereafter be recoverable hereunder. Section 37 4  of the Act reads as follows Whether the terms of an agreement to refer future differences to arbitration provide that any claims to which the agreement applies shall be barred unless numberice to appoint an arbitrator is given or an arbitrator is appointed or sonic other step to companymence arbitration proceedings is taken within a time fixed by the agreement and a difference arises to which the agreement applies, the Court, if it is of opinion that in the circumstances of the case undue hardships would otherwise be caused, and numberwithstanding that the time so fixed has expired, may on such terms, if any, as the justice of the case may require, extend the time for such period as it thinks proper.

arguments.claim: Undue hardship under s.37(4) requires special circumstances beyond mere barring of claim; strict view from early English cases

anchor.surface_text: Section 16 6  of the English Arbitration Act, 1934 which is practically the same as s. 27 of the English Arbitration Act of 1950 is in pari materia with s. 37 4  of the Act. Therefore, the interpretation placed by English Courts upon s. 16 6 . and s. 27 of the respective ,Acts has great persuasive value. The English companyrts originally took a very strict and narrow view ,of the words undue hardship.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: 33,000 by a delay of only a few days due to excusable inadvertence, that the charterers would number in any way be prejudiced by time being extended a

arguments.court_reasoning: Trend reversed to liberal view; ordinary meaning as excessive hardship disproportionate to fault

arguments.claim: Undue hardship means excessive hardship out of proportion to claimant's fault; factors include delay length, blameworthiness, stakes, prejudice, circumstances beyond control

anchor.surface_text: It may be recalled that it was on July 1, 1971 and September 21, 1971 that the respondent lodged its claim with the appellant to recover the loss suffered. Thereafter, various letters passed between the parties. Ultimately, on February 16, 1973, the appellant wrote the letter to the respondent stating that the claim papers submitted in companynection with the claim had been scrutinized by the appellant but that it was unable to accept liability for the loss. The respondent then wrote a letter to the appellant on 30-3-1973 companyplaining about the uncertain language used in the letter dated February 16, 1973 and calling upon the respondent to point out specifically under which clause of exclusion of liability in the policy and the appellant disclaim the liability.

arguments.claim: No material prejudice to appellant by extension; undue hardship to respondent given amount at stake (Rs 1,10,000) and delay reasons

anchor.surface_text: In the facts and circumstances of this case, we think the High Court exercised its discretion properly in extending the time. The companyduct of the respondent was reasonable. ... Both the amount at stake and the reasons for delay are material in companysidering the question of undue hardship. We do number think that any material prejudice would be, caused to the appellant by extending the time. There would be undue hardship if time is number extended, as the companysequences of number-extension would in any event be excessive and out of proportion to the fault of the respondent, if any, in number being prompt.

Keeping in view these principles, it has to be seen whether in the facts and circumstances of this case, there was reasonable and sufficient ground for number preferring the claim to arbitration within the time specified in clause 12 of the policy and whether there would be undue hardship to the respondent if time number extended.

The companyduct of the respondent was reasonable. ... There would be undue hardship if time is number extended, as the companysequences of number-extension would in any event be excessive and out of proportion to the fault of the respondent, if any, in number being prompt.

holdings.text: We do not say that the mere fact that a claim would be barred would be undue hardship

anchor.surface_text: We do number say that the mere fact that a claim would be barred would be undue hardship. But companysidering the amount involved and the reasons for the delay, we think it would be undue hardship to the respondent if time is number extended.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Qualifies test: requires more than simple barring, but here additional factors present

precedents.citation: Steamship Co. of 1912 etc. v. Indlo-American Grain Co. etc. 1

anchor.surface_text: Steamship Co. of 1912 etc. v. Indlo-American Grain Co. etc.  1  Lord Parkar, J. said It has been said, over and over again by this Court, that there must be very special circumstances for extending the time. Of companyrse, if a valid claim is barred, there is hardship, but that is number what is provided for by the clause, and before this Court can extend the time they must be satisfied that the hardship amounts in the particular case to undue hardship

precedents.case_name: Steamship Co. of 1912 v. Indo-American Grain Co.
precedents.cited_proposition: Strict view of 'undue hardship': requires very special circumstances beyond mere barring of a valid claim
precedents.cited_holding: there must be very special circumstances for extending the time. Of course, if a valid claim is barred, there is hardship, but that is not what is provided for by the clause... the hardship amounts in the particular case to undue hardship

precedents.citation: Watney, Comba, Raid Co. v. E. Al. Dower Co. Ltd. 2

anchor.surface_text: Watney, Comba, Raid Co. v. E. Al. Dower Co. Ltd. 2  Goddard, C.J. said I desire to say in the clearest possible terms that the mere fact that the claimant is barred cannot be held to be an 1.  1958  2 Lloyds Rep. 341. 2.  1956  2 Lloyds Rep. 129, 131. undue hadship, which is what the section requires to be found by the companyrt before it extends the time.

precedents.case_name: Watney, Comba, Reid Co. v. E. & A. Dower Co. Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Mere fact that claimant is barred by time limit does not constitute undue hardship
precedents.cited_holding: the mere fact that the claimant is barred cannot be held to be an undue hardship, which is what the section requires to be found by the court before it extends the time

precedents.citation: F. E. Hookway Co. Ltd. v. H. W. H. Hopper Co. 1

anchor.surface_text: F. E. Hookway Co. Ltd. v. H. W. H. Hopper Co. 1  where the buyers made an application for extension of time under S. 16 6  of the English Act of 1934, Denning, L.J. observed That the extent of delay in a relevant circumstances to be considered, that if the delay is number on account of the fault of the buyer, it would numberdoubt, be an undue hardship on him to hold the clause against him but, if the delay is his own fault, the hardship may number be undue as it may be a hardship which it is due and proper that he should bear.

precedents.case_name: F.E. Hookway & Co. Ltd. v. H.W.H. Hopper & Co.
precedents.cited_proposition: Relevant factors for undue hardship include extent of delay, fault of claimant, evidence of loss on sub-contracts
precedents.cited_holding: That the extent of delay in a relevant circumstances to be considered... if the delay is not on account of the fault of the buyer... undue hardship... another relevant circumstance was whether there was evidence of any loss on any sub-contracts

precedents.citation: Stanhope Steamship Co. Ltd. v. British Phosphate Commissioners 2

anchor.surface_text: Stanhope Steamship Co. Ltd. v. British Phosphate Commissioners 2 , Singleton. J., in delivering the judgment said What, then, is the meaning of undue hardship ? Undue, it is said by Mr. McCrindle, means something which is number merited by the companyduct of the claimant. That may be right. If the result of claimants being perhaps a day late is so oppressive, so burdensome, as to be altogether out of proportion to the fault, I am inclined to think that one may well say that there is undue hardship.

precedents.case_name: Stanhope Steamship Co. Ltd. v. British Phosphate Commissioners
precedents.cited_proposition: 'Undue hardship' means something not merited by claimant's conduct or out of proportion to the fault
precedents.cited_holding: Undue... means something which is not merited by the conduct of the claimant... if... out of proportion to the fault... undue hardship. Both the amount at stake and the reasons for the delay are material considerations

precedents.citation: Librarian Shipping etc. v. A King Sons 3

anchor.surface_text: Librarian Shipping etc. v. A King Sons 3 , the facts were these. A vessel was let on a voyage charter party in Centrocon from companytaining an arbitration clause under which any claim had to be made in writing and the claimants arbitrator had to be appointed within three months of final discharge. A fire occurred on board the vessel during leading. Both the owners and the charterers had claims against each other.

precedents.case_name: Liberian Shipping Co. v. A. King & Sons
precedents.cited_proposition: Liberal view of undue hardship: disproportionate consequences to fault, no prejudice to other side, relevant circumstances include delay length, amount at stake, prejudice, etc.; courts should give ordinary meaning not narrow
precedents.cited_holding: if a claimant makes a mistake which is excusable, and is in consequence a few days out of time, then if there is no prejudice to the other side, it would be altogether too harsh... undue must mean something which is not merited by the conduct of the claimant, or is very much disproportionate to it

anchor.surface_text: We dismiss the appeal but in the circumstances, it is necessary that further time should be given to the appellant to numberinate an arbitrator. We, therefore, extend the time one month from the date of this judgment to enable the appellant to numberinate its arbitrator.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; further time of one month from the date of judgment extended to the appellant to nominate its arbitrator.

Keeping in view these principles, it has to be seen whether in the facts and circumstances of this case, there was reasonable and sufficient ground for number preferring the claim to arbitration within the time specified in clause 12 of the policy and whether there would be undue hardship to the respondent if time number extended.

We dismiss the appeal but in the circumstances, it is necessary that further time should be given to the appellant to numberinate an arbitrator. We, therefore, extend the time one month from the date of this judgment to enable the appellant to numberinate its arbitrator.
